newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh, UNHCR seek end to Burma refugee crisis.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh, UNHCR seek end to Burma refugee crisis.

text.p: Bangladesh and the U.N. relief agency UNHCR on Tuesday began efforts to persuade thousands of Burmese Moslem refugees to end a hunger strike.
Relief and Repatriation Commissioner Qamrul Huda and UNHCR representative Van To Nguyen, based in the southeastern district of Cox's Bazar, left for the camps early on Tuesday, officials said.
"They will talk to the militant refugee leaders who had enforced the food strike," one government official told Reuters. "We are expecting the ice to start melting soon," he added.

Scores of Bangladesh's 21,000 Burmese refugees, known as Rohingyas, have fallen ill after activists enforced a mass hunger strike July 21 and refused rations to protest alleged government attempts to send them home by force.
Clashes between police and Rohingyas resisting repatriation on July 20 left nearly 20 people injured, forcing authorities to postpone the repatriation from the two camps.
"Forget the repatriation, we are now much more eager to persuade them to take food because any death out of starvation would trigger a far worse situation," one government official said on Tuesday.
The message by relief and government officials is that Dhaka would not send anyone home against their will.
"This assurance has already been communicated to the refugees when Huda visited the camps Monday evening. We are going to say it again today," one official in Cox's Bazar said by telephone.

The UNHCR had lodged a strong protest with the Bangladesh government over the alleged forcible deportation of the refugees from camps lining the highway from Cox's Bazar to Teknaf In Bangladesh's southernmost tip.
The refugees were also preventing mothers from taking children to medical centres in an effort to intensify their campaign to stay in Bangladesh.
Poverty-ridden Bangladesh sheltered some 250,000 Rohingyas who fled from west Burma's Moslem-majority Arakan province in early 1992 to escape alleged military persecution and forced labour.
Their lingering presence has angered local residents.

"Most of the Rohingyas crossed into Bangladesh to live an easy life and avoid hard physical work. Now their friends in Geneva and elsewhere are shedding tears over their so-called plight," said Mohammad Shahjahan, 37, a school teacher in Cox's Bazar.
